headline: Nebius: Lots Of Upside Levers
summary: Nebius rebrands with $700m funding from Nvidia and Accel, focusing on AI cloud platforms, offering potential upside for investors. Click for more on NBIS stock.

headline: Microsoft expects $800M charge after GM killed its robotaxi unit
summary: Microsoft (MSFT) expects an $800 million charge from its minority stake in General Motors (GM) now shut down the robotaxi unit. The tech giant made a strategic investment in the robotaxi business to better compete with Alphabet's (GOOG, GOOGL) Google, which owns Waymo. The charge will weigh on the current quarter's earnings report. Morning Brief Hosts Seana Smith and Brad Smith, break down what investors need to know. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here. This post was written by Naomi Buchanan.

headline: Uber Stock Is Rebounding Day After GM Scrapped Cruise Robotaxi Program
summary: Uber Technologies  ’ stock rebounded Thursday.  On Wednesday,  General Motors  announced the closure of its robotaxi program and sent shares of  Uber  a former partner, into a spiral.  Uber stock was up 3.6% while shares of ride-hailing peer Lyft gained 1%.

headline: Microsoft Expects $800M Impairment Charge After GM Axes Cruise Robotaxis
summary: Microsoft will take an $800 million impairment charge in its second quarter earnings report related to its investment in robotaxi startup Cruise after General Motors announced this week that it would halt the development of Cruise's autonomous vehicles.

raw.headline: Microsoft Expects $800M Impairment Charge After GM Axes Cruise Robotaxis
raw.summary: Microsoft will take an $800 million impairment charge in its second quarter earnings report related to its investment in robotaxi startup Cruise after General Motors announced this week that it would halt the development of Cruise's autonomous vehicles.

headline: With General Motors pulling the plug on Cruise, every American automaker except Tesla has called it quits on robotaxis
summary: Automakers like Ford Motors and Volkswagen had also once made big, billion-dollar bets on the future of ridehail—only to walk back those plans later.
